title: 105_hr3174
content:
The Act titled "Electronic Campaign Disclosure Act of 1998" mandates electronic preservation and filing of Federal Election Commission reports, with access through an internet site. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 was amended to establish a public Internet site for filing reports and accessing information through a competitive bidding process by January 1, 1999. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 was amended to establish an Internet site for filing reports. The Commission allows filing reports online or through designated electronic methods. Reports must be filed if contributions or expenditures exceed $25,000 in an election cycle. Verification methods for filed reports are provided by the Commission. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 was amended to require the Commission to make software available through competitive bidding for carrying out section 304(a)(11). The term "report" is defined as a report, designation, or statement required to be filed with the Commission. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 was amended to require the Commission to provide computer software for section 304(a)(11). The term "Internet" was redefined as an international computer network of Federal and non-Federal data networks. SEC. 3. REQUIRING REPORTING OF ALL CONTRIBUTIONS OF $100 OR MORE WITHIN 10 DAYS OF RECEIPT. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require political committees to electronically file reports listing contributions of $100 or more within 10 days of receipt, including contributor identification, date, amount, and candidate information. This report is in addition to other required reports under the Act. Expanding types of contributions to campaign committees subject to expedited reporting; shortening reporting deadline to within 24 hours of receipt. Section 304(a)(6) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require principal campaign committees to file reports electronically within 24 hours of receiving contributions over $100 after a certain date during an election cycle. SEC. 5. ELECTION CYCLE DEFINED.

The term 'election cycle' is defined as the period between the most recent general election and the next general election for candidates or authorized committees, and for all other persons, it is the period between the last general election and the next general election.

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The amendments made by this Act will apply to elections after January 1999.
